detailed_results.input: The world’s stable now. People are happy; they get what they want, and they never want what they can’t get. They’re well off; they’re safe; they’re never ill; they’re not afraid of death; they’re blissfully ignorant of passion and old age; they’re plagued with no mothers or fathers; they’ve got no wives, or children, or lovers to feel strongly about; they’re so conditioned that they practically can’t help behaving as they ought to behave.
detailed_results.reasoning: Gold states that the World can guarantee that stability holds globally (<<World>>G stable). The prediction instead requires happiness now and additionally that globally no error occurs (G !error), and it omits the stable predicate. This changes the propositions and adds extra constraints, so it is not semantically equivalent.

detailed_results.input: If we wish to fight, the enemy can be forced to an engagement even though he be sheltered behind a high rampart and a deep ditch. All we need do is attack some other place that he will be obliged to relieve.
detailed_results.reasoning: Prediction changes both coalition and meaning. Gold is a simple implication about 'We' with conditions (enemy sheltered behind rampart and ditch) implying 'attack_other_place'. Prediction uses coalition <<Robot1, Robot2>> and a temporal property G(attack -> F enemy_relieved), introducing different agents, different propositions, and different temporal structure (G/F) not present in the input/gold.
